awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT:  Physics-based Deep Transfer Learning for Predictive Maintenance of Industrial and Agricultural Machinery
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to provide the industrial and agricultural sectors with a practical and scalable solution for proactively predicting and preventing the failures of rotating machinery. An unexpected failure of a rotating machine may incur high maintenance and downtime costs, reduce customer satisfaction in a produced good, and cause human injuries and fatalities. These consequences not only impact the end user of the rotating machine, but also the machinery manufacturer by tarnishing its reputation and potentially impacting its competitive advantage. This PFI-TT project will accelerate the commercialization of deep learning in predictive maintenance to provide more accurate failure predictions than current solutions and is easily deployed across different types of machines and equipment. By making predictive maintenance practical and scalable, this project is expected to produce major advancements in developing machine systems that are more reliable and safer, as well as incurring lower maintenance and downtime costs than existing systems. Ultimately, the economic competitiveness of the U.S. industrial and agricultural sectors will be enhanced based on more reliable, safer and lower-cost rotating machinery.

The proposed project will create a cost-effective, easy-to-implement, easy-to-scale Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) platform for remotely monitoring machine health and predicting when and where maintenance actions need to be taken. The core of the proposed IIoT platform is a new deep learning solution that exploits the concepts of physics-based learning, transfer learning and online learning. To date, deep learning approaches to diagnostics/prognostics have been mostly relying on large volumes of training data and largely in isolation from the underlying physics of component faults. This project will overcome these limitations by integrating physics-based modeling and data-driven transfer learning. The resulting solution does not simply use run-to-failure data to train a deep learning model. Instead, training data is used, in conjunction with known physics and previously learned knowledge, to achieve more accurate predictions than possible from using training data alone. Additionally, the solution offers the capability of online learning that may lead to a paradigm shift in machinery prognostics toward unit-specific learning and prediction. The proposed deep learning solution has the potential to make predictive maintenance practical and scalable, thereby significantly promoting the wide-scale adoption of this maintenance strategy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this PFI project is to create a low-cost, easy-to-implement, massively scalable Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) platform for proactively predicting and preventing the failures of rotating machinery in industrial and agricultural applications. The core of the proposed IIoT platform is a deep learning solution that synthesizes transfer and online learning concepts. This platform was developed in collaboration with Percēv (the Industrial Partner and a subsidiary of Grace Technologies) and Grace Technologies. It consisted of three research thrusts: transfer learning for data-scarce machine applications (Thrust 1), online learning and prediction of component failures (Thrust 2), and validation of online proof-of-concept (Thrust 3).

 

This project has produced the following key results.

- We developed a new transfer learning approach to bearing failure prognostics that automates the processes of generating high-quality synthetic data and training a predictor using a combination of synthetic and real data. Our effort can reduce the need for large training datasets, making it easier and faster for OEM maintenance practitioners to deploy deep learning models in data-scarce applications.

- We created a physics-informed feature weighting approach for bearing fault diagnostics. This approach can potentially bridge an important gap between physics-based modeling of bearing faults and data-driven diagnostics of these faults. This approach produced physics-informed deep learning models with much higher classification accuracy than several industry baselines.

- We demonstrated an IIoT deployment of a physics-informed deep learning model for bearing fault diagnostics inside Percēv’s GraceSense™ line of IIoT smart devices. For the first time, a physics-informed deep learning model was deployed on a microprocessor-based IIoT device, in which edge computing produced a real-time evaluation of bearing health without the need for expensive computational infrastructure. This decentralized approach can avoid unacceptable delays in safety-critical applications, filling a knowledge gap in performing real-time health inference with large deep learning models on resource-limited edge devices.

- We created a clustering-based federated learning approach for machinery health monitoring, especially applicable to industrial and agricultural applications where multiple clients reside on an IIoT platform and can all collect fault data. This effort improved our understanding of collaboratively training models across multiple clients whose training datasets follow significantly different input data distributions (domain shifts within training data) and miss certain fault types.

 

Broad impacts of the project are the following. (i) The transfer learning approach represents an important step towards successfully commercializing IIoT platforms for failure prognostics and predictive maintenance. (ii) The methodology validation and IIoT deployment of the physics-informed feature weighting approach can increase the practical adoption of physics-informed deep learning models for online, on-the-edge bearing diagnostics. This increased adoption will result in machine systems that are more reliable and safer and incur lower maintenance and downtime costs than existing systems, ultimately increasing the economic competitiveness of the U.S. industrial and agricultural sectors. (iii) The clustering-based federated learning approach can potentially broaden the application of federated learning to practical IIoT applications where client datasets are heterogenous and miss certain fault types. (iv) Engaging  five Ph.D. and one undergraduate student in research helped them gain knowledge and experience in vibration data acquisition and analysis, bearing diagnostics and prognostics, and machine learning. (v) A two-time internship experience allowed the Ph.D. student to gain experience working in a start-up company, improve professional communication skills, and develop a research vision for addressing societal needs. (vi) The results of this project were actively shared with other researchers and industry partners through conference presentations and invited discussions. 

 


Last Modified: 03/03/2023
Modified by: Chao Hu
